newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Philippines, Swiss to step up efforts over Marcos money.
newsitem.headline: Philippines, Swiss to step up efforts over Marcos money.

text.p: The Philippines and Switzerland have agreed to step up efforts to resolve a decade-old battle over $500 million in assets kept in Swiss banks by late president Ferdinand Marcos, the government said on Tuesday.

President Fidel Ramos and Swiss Federal Councillor Jean-Pascal Delamuraz met on Monday and agreed to facilitate the resolution of conflicting claims over the fortune frozen in Switzerland, a presidential palace news release said.

"President Ramos and Councillor Delamuraz agreed it to be in the best interest of both the Philippines and Switzerland that a solution be found to this long and complicated problem as early as possible," the release quoted Swiss Ambassador Kurt Hochner as saying.
The solution being sought would be "in a manner consistent with the laws of both countries," Hochner said.
The money held in Swiss banks is part of what the Philippine government alleges is some $5 billion looted from the economy by Marcos and his associates during his 20-year rule.
Marcos was ousted in a 1986 popular revolt and died in exile in Hawaii three years later. He and his family denied they plundered the Philippine treasury.

Besides Manila and the Marcos family, the fortune is also being claimed by victims of human rights abuses during the Marcos rule and by a company representing a late Filipino locksmith who had accused Marcos of stealing a Buddha statue supposedly made of gold which the locksmith said he found in a treasure hunt.
Swiss justice officials last month said in Zurich they had asked the Swiss supreme court to make it easier to hand the money over to Philippine authorities.

Specifically, they asked the court to drop its insistence in a 1990 ruling that the money only be returned once a Philippine court issued a binding sentence on the Marcos family and ordered the money confiscated.
Manila has filed scores of criminal and civil suits against former first lady Imelda Marcos, accusing her of helping her husband loot the economy.
A Manila court convicted her in one case in 1993 and sentenced her to 18 years in jail but Marcos is appealing the decision and remains free on bail.
The palace statement did not say what kind of solution was being worked out.
